title: The Urgency of Bhakti in a Godless World | Sri Vasudev Keshav Dasa | Sri Gaura Mandala Parikrama
speaker: HG Vasudev Keshav Dasa

segments.key_quote: The duration of life is immaterial, but the duty of a dying man is very important.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces Maharaj Pariksit's two questions about duty in life and at the time of death, explaining their significance and how the Srimad Bhagavatam addresses them, emphasizing devotional service as the ultimate duty.
segments.transcript: Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, first canto, 19th chapter, 24th verse, appearance of Shukadev Goswami. Translation, O trustworthy brahmanas, I now ask you about my immediate duty. Please, after proper deliberation, tell me of the unalloyed duty of everyone in all circumstances and specifically of those who are just about to die. Purport, in this verse, the king has placed two questions before the learned sages. The first question is, what is the duty of everyone in all circumstances? And the second question is, what is the specific duty of one who is to die very shortly? Out of the two, the question relating to the dying man is most important, because everyone is a dying man, either very shortly or after 100 years. The duration of life is immaterial, but the duty of a dying man is very important. Maharaj Pariksit placed these two questions before Shukadev Goswami also on his arrival. And practically the whole of Srimad Bhagavatam, beginning from the second canto up to the last 12th canto, deals with these two questions. The conclusion arrived at thereof is that, devotional service of Lord Srikrishna, as it is confirmed by Lord himself in the last phases of the Bhagavad Gita, is the last word in relation to everyone's permanent duty in life. Maharaj Pariksit was already aware of this fact, but he wanted the great sages assembled there to unanimously give their verdict on his conviction, so that he might be able to go on with his confirmed duty without controversy.

segments.key_quote: The first class method demands that one give up all other methods and surrender unto the lotus feet of Lord and thus be saved from all sins and their reactions.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the importance of asking the right questions and highlights the significance of surrendering to the Lord as the ultimate path to self-realization, emphasizing that the entire Srimad Bhagavatam is based on these two questions.
segments.transcript: He has specifically mentioned the word Shuddha or perfectly correct. For transcendental realization or self-realization, many processes are recommended by various classes of philosophers. Some of them are first class methods and some of them are second or third class methods. The first class method demands that one give up all other methods and surrender unto the lotus feet of Lord and thus be saved from all sins and their reactions. So in this verse, Parikshit Maharaj is asking something very important to all the sages who have assembled there in the forest of Naimisharanya. He has just been cursed by the son of the Rishi, Sringi, that boy. And the curse is that he is supposed to die in seven days. He receives a death notice, something very unique, Prabhupada writes. And he is asking two very, very important questions. Prabhupada writes that the quality of question itself is so wonderful. Just the question itself is so wonderful. What are the two questions he is asking? Number one, what is the ultimate duty, the unalloyed duty of everyone in all circumstances? Not just what is my duty, his duty. Everyone's duty, unalloyed duty, the highest duty in all circumstances. It's like everything is covered in this. And then the second question that he is asking is, and the duty of someone who is about to die immediately. These are the two questions and Prabhupada writes in the purport, the entire Srimad Bhagavatam is based out of these two questions. Right from the second canto, this is the 19th chapter of the first canto. The first canto is ending now. And now the second canto to 12th canto is all based on these two questions.

segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the unpredictable nature of death through the story of his neighbor who died unexpectedly, highlighting the urgency of fulfilling one's duty in life.
segments.transcript: So Prabhupada writes, Who is not a dying man? Everyone is a dying man. We cannot say, generally people think dying means old age. But no, we cannot be so sure when death will come. Death may come any moment. There is no guarantee. And in that way, Prabhupada says, everyone is a dying man. There was one of my neighbors, we stayed in Calcutta for about 20 years. And one Mr. Mittal Ji, we shared the same floor. We were next door neighbors. We used to spend time there. They used to spend time there. I knew them very well. So just not long time ago, but very recently I got a news about him that he passed away. It was very shocking how he passed away. He was a very hale and healthy man, very nice person, very gentle. And he had built a new house and he was supposed to be doing Griha Pravesha. There was so much of excitement and happiness in the entire family. He has three children and the pujas were supposed to begin. And he was supposed to go, the Pandit Ji told him that can you please go and bring some puja items for the puja. Something was missing or something like that. So he went to bring some puja items from the market and then family members are waiting for him to come back. And he is not returning. And then after a while it was a matter of concern what happened. And then somehow they got a call after some time that he is, who is this and he is your father and he is on the road and please come. He looks like something has happened. Please come and they were all shocked and they rushed to the place from where the call came. And what had happened actually, he was carrying the puja items or something like that. He was walking and he was going and one vehicle came and hit him. It was not a very big hit, it was a small hit. And he fell down, the way he fell down something on his brain got hurt. And he was rushed to the hospital. And the doctor says 24 hours is very critical. We cannot say anything like that. But as Krishna had desired after 24 hours he passed away. This news came as a big shock. Imagine the excitement, griha pravesha, new house, new apartment. And this is what happened and nobody had any idea about it.

segments.key_quote: Every moment we must remind ourselves that we have a very important duty. And I must complete that duty before I die.
segments.summary: The speaker shares a near-death experience and emphasizes the importance of taking devotional service seriously and becoming Krishna conscious quickly, as it is the ultimate duty.
segments.transcript: So every moment we must remind ourselves that we have a very important duty. And I must complete that duty before I die. Just yesterday it happened. We were all travelling to Haridas Thakur's birthplace and we were in the first vehicle. Ten of us were there. And just we were driving, the driver was driving, it was at a medium speed. And just about 15-20 meters ahead of us one big tree branch just fell on the road. It was like first time live we saw it. It got captured on the video. And it was a fraction of 3-4 seconds. If we were 3-4 seconds ahead. It was a huge one. It occupied the entire expanse of the road. It just fell. It was some old tree or something like that. And see how Krishna saved us. So this verse is actually talking about how seriously we must take to devotional service. What is the unalloyed duty of everyone in all circumstances. The question itself is so serious. I must become Krishna conscious very soon, very quickly. Because unless and until you become perfectly Krishna conscious, we have not actually done our duty.

segments.key_quote: But one must be very serious and sincere.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the importance of humility and sincerity in prayer and devotional service, emphasizing that Krishna will purify and deliver those who are serious and sincere.
segments.transcript: We chant that verse, Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu doya koro more. Toma bina ke dayalu jagata samsare. And what is the second verse? Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu doya koro more. And what is the second line? Patita pavan hetu tavey avataar. Mosama patita Prabhu na paiy beyaar. So we sing this every day. And then we say, we offer a prayer to Krishna, that Krishna, I am the most fallen. And since I am the most fallen, my claim is first on being delivered. Please claim me. I am the most fitting candidate for being delivered. And then your name as Patita, your name as Patita Pavana will be truly glorified. We pray like that. Prabhupada in one place writes something more than this. Yes, we can pray. Definitely we should pray that I am the most fallen so my claim is first. But then in what should be a mood and what should be a consciousness of praying and a practice of devotional service. So Prabhupada quotes these two lines and then soon after that he writes, But one must be very serious and sincere. It is not that yes, it is good to pray that I am the most fallen and so please deliver me first. But we should be very sincere, very serious and then Krishna will deliver us from, He will purify us from all contamination surely and certainly. So actually if we read Srila Prabhupada's books, we will get this sense. This sense should be absorbed from Srila Prabhupada. Prabhupada's life itself, he is a living example of how serious and sincere he was. Writing books, midnight, 12 o'clock, getting up at 4 o'clock. You see the seriousness and how serious Prabhupada was in spreading Krishna consciousness. With just 40 rupees, he is trying, he is struggling, he is endeavouring. And all over his lectures, all over his books, He gives this impression to us that we must be very serious and sincere.

segments.key_quote: Intensive devotional service is the only means to attain final perfection.
segments.summary: The speaker stresses the importance of intensive devotional service as the only means to achieve final perfection in Krishna consciousness, emphasizing the need to be 100% Krishna conscious to return to Godhead.
segments.transcript: There is one, recently I read one line. So just to give you a sense of how Prabhupada through his teachings is talking, stressing about seriousness and sincerity. So this is one line which talks and like this you can find innumerable lines. We practice devotional service as practice of devotional service is the means to attain perfection. So there are three words here. Practice of devotional service is the means to attain perfection. Now for each of these three words, one more word has been added. We must practice intensive devotional service, not just devotional service. And intensive devotional service is the only means to attain final perfection in Krishna consciousness. So look at the word. Intensive devotional service is the only means for final perfection of Krishna consciousness. So we all have to go for the final perfection. Even if we are 99.9% Krishna conscious, there is no going back to Godhead. We have to be 100% Krishna conscious.

segments.key_quote: Ekina manasa means with one pointed attention.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes verses emphasizing the importance of hearing, chanting, remembering, and worshiping with one-pointed attention, urging devotees to reflect on the intensity of their devotional service.
segments.transcript: And that is why, the reply to these two questions. What is the answer that Shukadev Goswami is giving? Tasmad ekina manasa. Tasmad. Okay, there are many verses. But yeah, this is exactly. There are. Tasmad. So Tasmad Bharata Sarvatma. Read that. Bhagwan Ishwaro Harihi. Shotavya. Kirti Tavyasya. Gheya. Smrtavya Cha. Chitavayam. Chitavayam. Achitavayam. So and actually there are many verses. And one more place. So this is one verse where he is talking about. Tasmad Bharata Sarvatma. Bhagwan Ishwaro Harihi. Sarvatma. Everyone. Bhagwan Ishwaro Harihi. And what they should do? Hear, chant, remember, worship. And in another place Shukadev Goswami is saying. Tasmad ekina manasa. Bhagwan Satvatam Patihi. Shotavya. Kirti Tavyasya. Gheya. Pujas. Cha. Nityadhar. Ekina manasa. Ekina manasa means with one pointed attention. Another way. A perfect reply for a perfect question. One should, Shotavya, Kirti Tavyasya, hear, chant, Gheya, remember, Pujas, worship, Cha, Nityadhar, Nityadhar means constantly. So devotees should actually reflect on all these things, that am I doing my devotional service with this intensity, with this force. In another place Prabhupada is right. We should not be doing devotional service casually, but we should be doing devotional service seriously, constantly. So this Govarmandal Parikshan, Parikrama that we are all out, it's an opportunity for us during these 20 days to actually engage in this intensive practice of devotional service, because Ekina manasa. It is very, it is sometimes, because we are not, we are still conditioned. We are not on that stage where we can practice this 24 hours. But at least these 20 days that we have, we should take this opportunity, remember these instructions and make the best use of this opportunity that is there. I must at least for these days, Shotavya, Kirti Tavya, Shadheyya, Poojas, Cha Nityada, Ekina Manasa. All these things can be practiced.

segments.key_quote: We must keep reminding ourselves of these instructions.
segments.summary: The speaker encourages listeners to pray to Srila Prabhupada for help in practicing devotional service with sincerity and eagerness, expressing gratitude for the opportunity to engage in intensive practice.
segments.transcript: It is not very difficult. It is just that we need to be in that consciousness. We need to keep, we must keep reminding ourselves of these instructions and pray to Srila Prabhupada, that Srila Prabhupada please help me. I wish to do. So before we get into this mood, first a desire should be there and a prayer, a heartfelt prayer should be there, that yes Prabhupada I want to do like this. I am unable to do like this and please help me. And so when Prabhupada sees that a devotee is very sincere and very eager in becoming like that, we will be blessed with this opportunity. So like yesterday we were there in such a wonderful place, Haridas Thakur Samadhi and sorry, Bhajan Kotir and the appearance place. And we saw that tree also. It was so much different. So it all, all these, this is a very one, I am realizing now after coming here. You know that what a wonderful, we have read. So all these pastimes in CC and different places of Prabhupada. But when you come here and you be in that place, I am sure all of you have this experience. Some of you shared also. It is so much different from just reading. It is giving us, this intensive practice of devotional service actually comes so easily. So we should be grateful to Prabhupada, be grateful to all the devotees who have you know organized this, because so nicely it is coming, so easily it is coming.

segments.key_quote: You should be possessing one lakh holy names every day.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates a pastime of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, explaining how He defined 'Lakshishwar' not as a millionaire, but as one who chants one lakh holy names every day, emphasizing the importance of chanting.
segments.transcript: And it's a, so yesterday we read that story of Hira Devi, right? Hira Devi, Lakshah, Lakshah, Lakshah, Lakshah. No, she was Hira Devi, Hira Bai. Hira Bai. Hira Bai she was. Later she became Lakshahira. A small pastime which I heard something about Lakshahira. So Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, he would, devotees would invite Chaitanya Mahaprabhu for the, for lunch. That was a, that was a system, that 12 o'clock, the noon time lunch, Mahaprabhu would take in the house of devotees. And all the devotees, he was very eager to host Chaitanya Mahaprabhu to, because that was a devotional service and they wanted to do that. And Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, he realized that he is receiving too many invitations. So every day you can accept only one invitation. But there were so many devotees of Lord Chaitanya that every day he was receiving 3 to 4 invitations. So Mahaprabhu had to devise a method by which, you know, it is reduced to just one invitation. So he says from today I am going to accept invitations from only those devotees who are Lakshishwar. Lakshishwar. Lakshishwar means, it is something synonymous to, in Calcutta, Lakpati. Lakpati. It was a very well known term. This is about 30 years back. Lakpati means, now a days it is all crorepati. Lakpati is gone. Millionaire. So, Lakpati means, you possess a lakh of rupees. You can imagine what a Laksh, Lakpati would be during Chaitanya Mahaprabhu's time. But there were, Hiranya and Gordhan Majundar were there like that. So, so, Mahaprabhu says, from today I am going to accept invitations only from these people. So everybody thought, oh my god, Lakpati. None of them were Lakpati. They were all very simple devotees. Kola, Vicha, Shridhara, you know what he was. So they thought that, okay, from today then we can't host Mahaprabhu because that is the condition that he has placed. And then Mahaprabhu said something. He was actually basically trying to impress upon, stress upon, intensive devotional service. He said, no, Lakshishwar means, Ishwar means a lord of one lakh, not one lakh rupees. You should be possessing, not one lakh rupees, you should be possessing one lakh holy names every day.

segments.key_quote: Except chanting, a person has no other duty.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of chanting, highlighting that it is the only duty in this human form of life, and mentions Srila Prabhupada's instruction to chant 16 rounds minimum.
segments.transcript: So, and this is what Gaudiya Math was actually. They were chanting one lakh holy names every day, 64 rounds. And actually if you see, Srila Prabhupada also in the initial days, he told, you chant 64 rounds. And that is why our rule is, 16 rounds minimum. That word minimum is there. So all these things, when you read and hear, it is actually stressing on this word, intensive practice of devotional service. And this is our duty, only duty, for everyone, in all circumstances. In one place Srila Prabhupada is saying, directly is pointing out, except chanting, a person has no other duty. Except chanting, there is no other duty in this holy, in this human form of life. So basically all these things, you know, it is stressing. So at least 16 rounds, yes finally we have 16 rounds with us and we should stick to 16 rounds and engage ourselves in devotional service, because that is what finally Prabhupada gave us. But these 16 rounds must be of good quality. And if you, in 1976, there are many letters that Srila Prabhupada, Prabhupada keeps writing so many letters to different devotees. If you search the Veda base, in 1976, it is 76 or 75, one of these years, Prabhupada is writing to disciples, that please chant 16 good rounds. And if you search on this, 16 good, he is not saying please chant 16 rounds. He is stressing something, chant 16 good rounds.

segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of chanting 16 good rounds, citing Srila Prabhupada's letters and a devotee's explanation that chanting all rounds in one go constitutes good rounds.
segments.transcript: So we should ask ourselves, am I chanting good rounds? And he doesn't write this to one disciple. In one year, he writes about 16 letters. In all the 16 letters, this line is repeating, please chant 16 good rounds. So our prayers to Srila Prabhupada and this should be a prayer to all the Leelas Thalis that we visit today, that Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, today we are going to Roop Sanatan, place where they did their bhajana. Let us offer this prayer. I am sure all of you are offering, that please help me in doing, you know, chanting good rounds and doing intensive practice of devotion service, so that we become more serious and become perfect before we meet our last days. Thank you. Anybody wishes to say something on the 16 rounds, good rounds. Srila Prabhupada said that 16 rounds good rounds means you chant them all in one go. Ok very good. You chant them all in one go, because that is good rounds. Ok. If you chant, if you chant the rounds, here one here two there three there, by the time it is evening, you just want to chew them up. If we can chant all rounds, all together 16 rounds, the whole day will be a complete different day. I have also realized this and I am sure many devotees would have also realized this. All in one go and that is really, that is a good definition of 16 good rounds. . . . .
